reviewText:
Early Access Review

One of the first reviews for the game, now that the dev has got the missing executable error sorted out!
Where to start, where to start...
(scroll down for tl;dr)

The moment I started this, there I was, docked in the middle of a city, with a text tutorial and no idea at all how to do anything. My half hour spent on the game has been spent working out game mechanics, flying, buying, missions and all of that.

The graphics are real pretty for an indie game by a small dev team. Flying up into the atmosphere and seeing all of nothing around you, seeing planets, suns, space stations and cities from a distance. Ive only seen Earth and the moon from the Sol solar system, and seen countless random other planets and stations in other random systems, but so far I am impressed with the depth, size and look of the game.

Flying is a little weird - you use the mouse to do most movement, but you also need to use the A and D buttons for the roll function. Switching out of the mouse movement mode to go to autopilot, manuever and transit modes.
It may take a little while to get used to still.
Edit: So it would appear that there is the option to change your key bindings and mouse usage, also being able to us the directional keys to control the ship. Apparently there is partial controller support at this stage too, though I am yet to try it.

So far I have worked out how to get off the planet, learnt how to get around to others, learnt how to dock at cities and space stations, learnt all the interfaces.. but getting a mission that requires me to leave the starting area? As of What this needs is a more comprehensive tutorial, I think, but as its only build 7 of Alpha, and super early, all in good time :)
Edit: Finally worked out how to get out of the starting system to explore the universe in its glory. Hydrogen and jump drives. Who knew.

Remember, its only in alpha, and really early alpha at that. Its playable, but the learning curve at this stage is steep. There's a few killer bugs as well (my autopilot into a space station killed me for example) but nothing too game breaking.
I have high hopes for this, and it already looks really promising.
Definitely worth the money I paid to support it - but don't expect a totally finished game because you'll be disappointed.
I will update this once I learn more features and the game is updated :)
The devs are pretty cool too, and are really active on the paragon forums and are really interested in what the community has to say. They are really intent on making this game the best it can be!


tl;dr
- Im loving this game.
- Its pretty
- No comprehensive tutorial as of yet
- Control scheme may be a bit difficult to handle at first
- Steep learning curve
- Bugs. Its in alpha. Expect bugs.
- Pretty sweet devs
- Its pretty.

This is the first early access game i fully support and actually want to help find bugs to help make it a better experience once finished!

On a less serious note, flew about 5km into a gas giant and exploded. 10/10 for realism.

Note: I have now made a comprehensive early game tutorial in the guides section explaining certain mechanics for new players. Lots of pictures and numbers. Hope it helps.
voteText: 132 of 141 people (94%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There is one thing we have to get out of the way:  Paragon is a mod/fork of the open source space sim Pioneer, a modern reworking of the great space sim Elite by David Braben that we were all raving about since 1984. As it stands this is as close as you are going to get right now to having Elite itself on steam, which is no bad thing ......
Well worth the purchase price for that little convenience alone.

So the 80s style (done perfectly) comes as no surprise, and the artwork (cockpits etc) are good quality.
Music is top notch as well, hinting at radiophonic and kraftwerk, it goes to make a perfect background to this space sim.  Runs like a dream and you can max the graphics on a modest PC.
It really does have the spirit and feel of Elite.

So my recommendation is a thumbs up with crossed fingers, trusting that the development of Paragon will continue along its own lines and not fall down like so many other early access titles have been doing on steam over the last few months.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nUnfortunately, this game has become all but unplayable over the past months. Issues ranging from consistent long load times (or the more likely failures requiring hard resets) at start up to freezes at the end of nearly every jump and worse. I gave it a shot because of the cheap price and concept, but as of 12/17/2014 it may as well be a pet rock. I wish the dev team good luck and hope one day to be given a reason to revise this review, but I cannot in good faith recommend this work in progress and suggest others avoid purchasing this alpha title until extensive work has been done to improve the overall game environment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All I can give right now are very early impressions, but so far Paragon seems like a very competent Elite clone. The game has a great look, and even with some clearly WIP UI screens, it presents information neatly and accessibly. Plus, the music is really quite nice. (Though I've silenced it to play Nujaubes, which also happens to complement the game very well...)

So far, most complaints are simply symptomatic of the game's alpha status. Early-game balance is very lacking, with early delivery missions (the only ones you'll be able to take) paying anywhere between $400-700, while ships bigger than the miniscule starting ship costing upwards of $50000. This will presumably be changed in future revisions, but in the mean time, all ship info is stored in convenient little .lua files within the game's folders, so manually changing ship prices is a good way to circumvent the early grind.

Also, another minor complaint: currently there just aren't enough keyboard shortcuts. Clicking through the (again, very attractive and thoughtfully designed) menus would be a more painless process if there were shortcut keys to flip between your ship's views, comms, maps, etc. I assume this is on the to-do list somewhere, because it's such a simple thing.

Oh, and the autopilot can be downright homicidal. This seems to be true of most space games, but the moral of the story is save frequently and try to keep an eye out for passing freighters when you're docking or taking off from a station.

Bottom line, though, Paragon is a compelling and promising space sim. It definitely leans more towards approachability and simplicity than the impregnable X series, or the finnicky Evochron Mercenary (both of which are also good), though it seems that Paragon is aiming towards a fair amount of depth eventually. In the mean time, it's an attractive little Elite-clone and easily worth the $15.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Minimalistic, clean retro style and music of Paragon is fantastic. It's really immersive. Unfortunately at the current state the game is unplayable because of serious bugs (mainly suicidal autopilot, buggy docking bays and crashing). You must constantly save and even when you reach your destination, it's uncertain whether you'll dock (or take off). Buy it only if you want support developers. Paragon has potential, but give it some time yet.

I'll edit my review (and change recommendation eventualy) after updates which will fix these bugs.

Tips: If you want tutorial go to http://pioneerwiki.com/wiki/Manual (Paragon is an opensource fork of Pioneer). You have no guns at the beginning. For hyperjump you need Jump module and hydrogen and you must be at least 15km above the surface. Docking is possible only via autopilot (A) and you must first ask for permission. Trading is useless at the beginning, so earn cash trough delivery between sectors (~1000 $).
voteText: 11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well what could be better than wanting to explore an entire galaxy of stars and planets (and even moons)? Not much this observer thinks but then what if you add space stations and cities or spaceports into the mix? It's not illusion in paragon, it's all there and that concept alone is the basis of a game with plenty of depth. But of course i'm not just reviewing one side but all and so far the plot, as an avid sci-fi fan myself, is very interesting but still has much development. It is curently based in the not so distant future, around the 22nd century if i'm not mistaken, in a world where the Cold War doesnt end!

So far however, this plot has yet to be implemented fully and more technical issues have to be solved around how such a massive procedurally generated galaxy can be kept stable and in working order. I take my hat off to the devs who are attempting this task because from what i've seen already if these technical issues, minor and major, can be handled I honestly believe this could be one hell of an adventure.

With regards to the depth of the game, this is also something that is wanting but from the hammer and sickle on the space stations to maps of various aligned and non-aligned planets it seems the basis is there to create a universe of mixed politics and motives. Its one thing to play an rpg or free roaming games based in some distant land or with compulsory missions to weigh you down, but to have free reign to go about your business and make a name for yourself? That doesnt sound too bad and the potential is there.

As it is you can fly around, see the sights, get a feel for how the game would work and with enough imagination have some idea of the end product but it is a long way off and despite my enthusiasm it has to be said that getting involved with an early access program with massive scope is not for the faint of heart and so only those of patience (and a definite love for sci-fi) should apply now, otherwise give it time!

Im gunna keep this short and simple as i dont usually do this.

When all said and done, the game is worth the money.
I hope the developer keeps going in a good direction with this one because like i said, the potential is there, its awsome!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

From a basic point of view it's Grand Theft Auto in Space. You start small, build your way up doing various tasks to try and make some money, and next thing you know you're swimming in your mass amounts of hydrogen, killing people for thousands of dollars at a time, and building up your crew.

10/10

(On a more serious note this game was by far my favorite game on Desura and made my top favorites list on Steam. The game is beautiful, and even in it's alpha state has a lot to do! You can of course expect bugs and issues with the game as it is still in alpha of course, but I found it easy to look past those issues and just enjoy the game. Seriously, 10/10)

It's a good game, the game is on a good route to improve and evolve. The graphics are nice and the ships looks nice and handles diffrenetly from eachother. there are some missions to play most of them is about going to A to B to deliver somehing in a timeframe. reviewText:
Early Access Review

I gotta say Paragon is not a mod nor a port of Pioneer (which in itself is a remake of Elite II: Frontier) but at this point just a blatant reskinning. Virtually everything is identical to Pioneer expect for slightly higher quality graphics with a bit of post processing. Though I was keenly aware of the similarities before I bought this game the promotional videos and info I had read about the game on their site beforehand made it seem that  -even at this early alpha state- they had improved  on some of the base features of Pioneer. Sadly that is not the case at all (at least not as of now).

In fact they managed to screw up some basic mundane things that were already working well in Pioneer. For instance, simple things like word wrapping in menus and UI. A large part of Pioneer's and subsequently Paragon's gameplay has you pouring through resource lists, menus and just general text. At HD resolution (1920x1080) the font is oversived, janky, somewhat fuzzy and in certain areas words or phases overlap making it a puzzle to decipher if you aren't already familar with what it is supposed to say. That's a big part of the game and if that's not formatted properly well that certainly degrades the experience.

Another simple thing - In Pioneer when you visit various stations and or cities on planets throughout the universe the station personnel is represented by dynamically generated character pictures, made from snippets of male and female facial features of varying ethnicities and...silly mismatched sci-fi type gear. There are like 10 distinct facial features that are aslo mismatched to make somewhat unique (if not sometimes terrifying and creepy O.O) variations of characters to interact" (they are just photos with text underneath them but use your imagination) with. Did Paragon improve upon this aspect at all? No
date: in fact they replaced that quirky dynamic character generating system with a very boring single
recommended: all encompassing male or female faceless avatar. I mean really? Maybe that's something that will be changed in the future but who knows.\n\nThese may seem like little things but if they can't get these things right
hoursPlayed:
well you get the picture.

I personally regret the purchase and would rather just support Pioneer which is free and open-source. It's kind of shameful in my opinion that the Paragon devs are even making money off essentially a straight forward clone of a free game. Maybe in the future they will be able to develop enough unique content as to separate their game from Pioneer but as of now it is a mirror image of Pioneer with just an extra bit of visual polish.

If I am somehow woefully misinformed and Paragon was intended to be a visual upgrade mod of Pioneer then my question is how did it get Greenlit on Steam? I seriously would like to know what is happening here."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Shows great promise. With TrackIR support, hotas support, etc and maybe some tweaks to how the craft is controlled, interfacing with on-board gauges and spotting ability, it could and probably will become a very enjoyable game. I'm a simmer myself with a full setup, so it felt a little unnatural to use a tophat to look around and fumble with some of the controls and interfacing when trying to navigate from system to system.

Having said that, the game is sure to turn into something unique and quite fun.

If you have fond memories of Descent 2, TIE Fighter(which wasn't really a sim, but comparable with modern hardware and a simulator lean) or like me; can't wait for Elite: Dangerous to come out, then this might be a good pickup to whet your thirst for simulator space flight and combat.

I have about 4 hours in this game.  I'm experiencing an ever escalating number of deal breakers:

1)  Auto-pilot mostly works.  That
votesHelpful:
is not the problem.  When it DOESN'T work is the issue.  Expect to crash into docks and die.  One work-around would be too...

2) Save often.  Except I'm experiencing a crash on save about 1 every 3 or 4 attempts.  So that leg of the journey (since the last successful save) needs to be repeated.  However upon landing (presumably due to the type of station) I again auto-pilot crash.

3)  So instead of grinding these nickel-and-dime missions
votesTotal: why not play around a bit?  I modified a ship price so that I could at least make more than a couple grand.  So I fitted up the Starling transport
votesFunny: found some folks wanting to go three jumps for $5000 and we set off.  Landed in the system and auto-piloted to the dock.  Requested clearance and told this impressive space taxi to land.  No auto-pilot crash... time to cash in!  Wait
commentsCount: it didn't land... It's just floating above the pad.  I manually bring the ship back out of position and tell the autopilot to land again.  ...Still not on the pad.\n\nAlright.  4 hours in
column16:
and I'll be watching for the next patch notes to decide whether it's time to give it another shot.

Update:  There was an announcement a week ago that the specific save crash I'm experiencing was fixed.  I'm running their current Hotfix (Alpha 7 HF2)...  Save issue still exists.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fork of the open source freeware game Pioneer, which is in itself a remake of Elite II. Try Pioneer for free and then of you enjoy it, buy this, as it looks and sounds a lot better.

The graphics have been massively improved as has the soundtrack. The game goes for a retro 80's feel (right down to the Cold War In Space scenario) and the optional filters that make it look like a 80's sci fi film or its being played on a cathode monitor!

The universe and the individual planets look wonderful and there is a plethora of stuff to do. As with the original elite, the intial progress in the game is extremely slow, but once you gain traction there is a fantastic and absorbing range of activities, you can be a pirate, an interstellar taxi driver, a trader or fight for one of the factions. There's no overarching plot as such, but your imagination can build your own as you play.

For the price, this represents better value for money than E:D by a long chalk (and you can land on fantastically rendered planets NOW).

The only problem is that it is still a little bit buggy. I cannot load a saved game from the start page, I have to begin a new game, play for 10-15 minutes and then load my older saved game which is a bit of a pain. There's the occasional CTD to, and the graphics can lag a bit when you don't expect them to (and likewise be extramely smooth when there's a lot going on)

The game is soon to be updated, hopefully to iron out the glitches and push it closer to beta. If you like space trading games, this is definitely one of the better ones that I have tried.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Serious potential here. Being a HUGE Elite and Frontier fan, this really ticks every box in terms of feel and gameplay.  Initially there were a few kinda serious bugs which meant progress was slow and severely restricted but the team have sorted these out and it now looks like its all systems go.

Flying around planets is really awesome, and is probably only going to get better - it beats Frontier in that regard already.

If you liked Frontier then you are going to get that itch scratched here, but please remember this is an Alpha release - nowhere near feature complete and there's not actually THAT much to do at the moment - but WELL worth the investment nonetheless.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

WARNING TO FEDORA LINUX USERS THIS GAME WILL NOT WORK IN IT'S CURRENT STATE.


As it should be obvious this game is a fork of the open source game called Pioneer" which is in turn based off of the 1995 game "Frontier : First Encounters" which was the third iteration of the original open world space simulation ELITE. Now I thought the idea of this fork of Pioneer with it's 80's theme was a great idea
date: however after I bought it and installed it I was immediately turned off. The aesthetic is barely 80's
recommended: the ships all look as if they were constructed from lego and the cartoon style texturing and shading just doesn't reflect what they were going for. Plus the music is much too modern sounding
hoursPlayed: they completely missed the mark on the whole 80's vibe. The sound design as of yet is lacklustre as well. (To be clear while I couldn't get it to even start on Fedora Linux it does run on Windows 7)\n\nRight now the game is pretty empty and there is not a whole lot to do
voteText: keep that in mind as you prepare to buy this fork of a much more complete FREE game for FIFTEEN US DOLLARS. I understand it's still in early access and I probably wouldn't have posted this
helpfulPercent: but when I told them the game would not properly initialize in Fedora Linux by opening a thread in the discussion area they said it would be fixed in the next update
votesHelpful: but when it turned out to still not start they deleted the thread. What kind of dev deletes support threads? This is unacceptable
votesTotal: as a user that payed good money for this game I should not be swept under the rug. >:("

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Paragon is what it is. A throwback to 80s movie magic. Back in those days tall hair reigned supreme, and the life-ending creation of self-entitlement worldwide through the birth of the cell phone had yet come to fruition. If you enjoy space, if you enjoy stars, and if you enjoy space and stars this game is for you.

*There are some minor issues I run into here and there, like crashing straight to desktop, or m y AI unable to dock at a station- however I have yet to have a gamebreaking issue arise. Most of the issues in this game are what you will find in most AAA-budget tittles.

- For the price, worth the buy, worth the time spent, and I cannot wait to see future development. Sure there are other games like X, Elite Dangerous, and upcoming No Man's Sky - but Paragon, with it's worlds, personality in writing, and excellent music defeinitely makes it stand apart from the rest. If you've tried those other games, and are left unsatisfied, this little gem will probably fill the voice and with a low price fairly hard to avoid.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Jumpdrive / Paragon has had an update to Alpha 11.

Is it worth getting? I would say so, yes, based on this update and the way the game seems to be heading now. This update isn't a revolution but it's a good step in the right direction for this game, the guys developing this have made quite a lot of progress in the space of a month. New ships, new cockpits, new space graphical effects with nebulas, a better autopilot, a better GUI for the autopilot, and just generally better polish and even slightly better frame rate.

This game is making sure and steady progress but you have to remember that this game is ALPHA which means a lot of the features that you want to see here are not finished yet.

What you have got is a Space simulation where you can pretty much go and do whatever you want, it is a sandbox, it is just that not all of the gameplay content and sandbox flavours are in their yet as the developers are adding to the games content as it develops.

What you do get is a MASSIVELY improved and MASSIVELY polished up version of Pioneer with lots of things which Pioneer will never have. This game features a complete graphical overhaul, a complete audio overhaul and also a complete ship and assets overhaul. The game feels polished, it has a more simplistic but refined UI and it is making progress in the right ways which makes development for this game actually feel exciting now.

Is the game worth £10? I would agree. Yes. If you liked Frontier you pretty much have the same game here as Frontier although the combat as of yet is not as developed as say other areas like trading and such. Though the devs have said they are going to be working on the combat area of the game.

Jumpdrive is a work in progress but it is developing, and if the updates develop at the rate which this one has, and the way in which Adel and co are doing then basically this game is going to develop pretty quickly.

Looking forward to Alpha 12.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Much more accessible than Pioneer.  Quite a bit easier to jump into and get going.  Love the new graphics.  Has great potential but is definitely EARLY alpha.  If you don't like buggy games that are in development, don't buy this and leave negative reviews.  We need all the space sims we can get!  We need the option to control the ship manually, maybe an advanced control mode that gives us full control.  The autopilot is as others have put it, suicidal.  Quite frankly it's the worst thing in the game at the moment, don't trust it to land your ship, or you'll be staring at a game over screen more often than not.

This game has a long way to go, but if it gets there, it's going to be amazing.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A little confusing. Actually I had no idea what to do. I travelled around for a while in a shuttle. Wow. Definitely alpha.

A simple couple of pre-set missions or a coms channel with hints would help that. A basic education about the concepts beyond the text blurb provided. I might go so far as to suggest rescue or recovery missions to avoid violence (and the inherent ratings/classification problems in various meat jurisdictions)

The physics seems to ignore newton, although at the scale set it's hard to tell... Newton was wrong but his ideas make for fun games (see Angry Birds), especially if you have all thrusters manually controllable. Imagine the awesome epicness of winning a battle with a limping ship using a gravitational slingshot.

The quickish mode of transit ( forgot what it's called ) seems to only accelerate. My keys are default - W and S - and S doesn't slow me down. It would be nice if it behaved like the latest idea I was reading about from NASA - creating a space/time vacuum in front of the ship. That would give some more control over speed. Not sure how it translates to code in the game engine, but it shouldn't be hard given that it's kind of newtonian.

Also, the joystick config sucks. Happy to offer my input as a joystick tester. I have a 3 axis, 4 button joystick, but the 3rd axis is physically set up as a throttle and this does not work well for this game given the current options.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Just bought it, understanding the game's not ready for stores just yet. However, I find an appalling lack of gameplay information about what presently DOES exist. The tutorial seems like an afterthought at best. It doesn't even guide you through your beginning at your first port. No help with knowing what you could do with your ship or crew or cargo or anything. Once you get out of port, you have no guidance towards any possible goals, including any missions you take. Apparently you need Hydrogen in your cargo bay to make a hyperspace jump. And you need to be away from the planet. And if your hyperspace button won't activate even then, if the map will let you click on your distant target but nothing else is functioning, well, that's just too bad, there's no in-game information and no out of game guides or tips or anything. Just make sure you have that hydrogen and the auto-pilot is buggy.
At present I can't recommend the game. It looks nice and is probably fun to play, if you already knew what you were doing before you ever started playing. And if bugs didn't catch you. If you have already played plenty of Elite and/or Pioneer, then maybe you'll have lots more good times.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've been in on this game since one of the early alphas. This was before it was on steam, and really before the space sim genre had begun to come back into fashion. Back then, this was one of the only hopes for an open world space trading simulator. It was buggy, unoptimised, unpleasant to play and to look at, but it was still one of the best things on offer. Today, it has too many competitors which are getting it right for these problems to be overlooked.
Unfortunately, I don't think this game can survive the rebirth of the space sim genre.
